text: One in three jobs held by women has been deemed ‚Äúessential.‚Äù To all the women on the frontlines of this crisis: thank you from the bottom of my heart.

I am honored to receive the Moms Demand Action for Gun Sense in America Gun Sense Candidate distinction. We must take action to pass common-sense gun reform. Too many of our communities have been devastated by gun violence.  I am committed to continuing to make this a top priority of mine in the Senate. Thank you to Moms Demand Action for their leadership on ending gun violence in our communities.

A national testing strategy is critical to safely reopening the economy again. Testing must not only be available and widespread, but also accessible to everyone. That‚Äôs why I worked so hard to make sure COVID-19 and antibody testing is free, even if you don‚Äôt have insurance.  How this administration has handled testing angers me. Unfortunately, in the Senate, we can‚Äôt legislate competence, but I am doing whatever I can to get the additional resources we need for testing and to push the administration to develop a plan.
We must do whatever we can to ensure our food workers are working in safe and sanitary conditions. Their health and well-being should be our top priority.

This past week, the Senate passed another coronavirus relief package that included funding for our hospitals, testing, and small business loans. There is still a lot of work to be done. I won‚Äôt stop listening to your needs and advocating for you at every level.

Climate change is an existential threat to humanity - and with #EarthDay earlier this week, it‚Äôs a great reminder of the bold action we need. Taking that action on climate change is good for our health, the economy and jobs, clean air and water, and it‚Äôs necessary for our future.
I love spending time in the great outdoors, and our national parks are a special and protected place to do that. Happy National Park Week!

This week ‚Äî and every week ‚Äî our campaign is so grateful for all of our incredible volunteers that are a part of Team Tina. You are the lifeblood of our campaign. Thank you for all you do! #NationalVolunteerWeek

Happy Earth Day! Today is an important reminder that we must be good stewards of our planet and commit to taking bold action to combat climate change. In the Senate, I have worked hard to advocate for policies to fix our climate crisis. And I promise you this: I won‚Äôt stop fighting ‚Äî there‚Äôs too much at stake.

Now more than ever, it‚Äôs important for us to be supporting Minnesota‚Äôs farmers. That‚Äôs why Minnesota Cooks - the Minnesota Farmers Union local foods outreach program - compiled a list of Minnesota family farms who are selling directly and safely to consumers. Find that list and a family farm near you here: www.minnesotacooks.org. Photo Credit: Katie Cannon

Widespread and reliable COVID-19 testing is essential. That‚Äôs why I am calling on Mike Pence, the Coronavirus Task Force, and FEMA Federal Emergency Management Agency to start a national inventory for testing supplies and develop a clear plan to address future supply shortages.

I am fighting to make sure no one gets left out of our coronavirus relief efforts. That‚Äôs why I am working to ensure families with dependents over 16, adults with disabilities, and college students get the help they need.

This past week we held a phone bank with Dan Feehan for Congress. Team Tina talked to hundreds of voters about the importance of our upcoming election. Thank you to everyone who made calls! Join us at our next phone bank here: https://bit.ly/2zaWMVN.

I worked hard to make sure the coronavirus relief package included legislation to prevent drug shortages during this public health crisis. It‚Äôs critical doctors have the resources they need to treat those in their care.

Right now, people need to focus on taking care of the health and safety of their families ‚Äî not struggling to pay student loans. That‚Äôs why I‚Äôm urging student loan companies to provide relief to borrowers of private student loans during this time.

Elizabeth Warren and I have proposed a plan to save our country‚Äôs child care system during this public health crisis.  It is critical we make a large investment in our country‚Äôs child care system to ensure frontline workers have access to the child care they need and to help child care providers that have closed open their doors again once people start heading back to work.  Parents will not be able to find safe, affordable, and reliable care for their children when they return to work if we do not address this crisis now.

There is no reason ‚Äî especially in the midst of a health crisis ‚Äî to ever block access to reproductive care. Abortion is time-sensitive, essential health care. Politicians shouldn‚Äôt get to decide if this care is medically necessary or not.
Let‚Äôs call this a beautiful but momentary setback. We‚Äôre ready whenever you are, Spring.

Hey, Amy Klobuchar - Here‚Äôs me and Archie in 1983 when our love was young. We meet your ‚Äúfirst picture challenge‚Äù with this shot where Archie and I met in New England. One year later we were married and moved to MN. Maggie Hassan and Jeanne Shaheen, you‚Äôre next!‚Ä¨

The creativity from Minnesotans continues. Families in Rochester are on the hunt to find the stuffed bears and animals that are peeking out of their neighbors‚Äô windows ‚Äî all while staying 6 feet apart! üêª
YES. Now let‚Äôs keep up the fight.  Thanks, Refinery29.

Last month, the Senate passed a bipartisan coronavirus package that provided much-needed aid to working families and small businesses. But that legislation did not include direct payments for families with children over 17, college students, and adults with disabilities. My bill, the All Dependents Count Act, will fix this oversight and help these families get the resources they need during this public health crisis.

Last week, the Trump administration made it clear they would not open up a special enrollment period for the Affordable Care Act. This could be devastating for many workers who have been laid off because of this public health crisis. We‚Äôve got to make sure that everyone can have access to affordable health care coverage.

During this unprecedented public health and economic crisis, our team asked you to donate to two incredible organizations serving Minnesota families: Second Harvest Heartland Food Bank and Meals on Wheels America. These nonprofits were in great need of resources to serve those most impacted by the coronavirus pandemic in our communities. Together, we raised nearly $40,000. I was amazed by your overwhelming response. Not only have you continued to support our campaign, but you went above and beyond to donate to these causes and I just wanted to take a moment to say thanks.
Got my home office set up last weekend and Moose decided to help out.

During this public health emergency, we have seen so many individuals step up and provide critical services for our communities. Childcare providers are among this heroic and important group, keeping their doors open so others have one less thing to worry about. Thank you to each and every one of you making sure our kids are cared for.

A powerful and humbling story of Minnesotans uniting to help each other during this time. Thanks to Du Nord Craft Spirits, Loaves & Fishes, and all of the other organizations working around the clock to care for one another.Today I had an experience I would like to share. A gentleman named Lonnie from Loaves & Fishes stopped by the distillery today to pick up hand sanitizer. If you are not familiar with Loaves and Fishes, they provide hot meals to anyone in need. While Lonnie was at the distillery, and through the course of our brief conversation, he mentioned that one of their sites was Holy Rosary Catholic Church and he gestured to the northwest. When I moved to Minnesota from Indiana in 1991, we were dirt poor. We picked up food from food shelves, and I wore donated clothes and/or whatever we could find at goodwill. During this time I learned to hate, but tolerate, the orange/yellow blocks of government cheese we were given, and food stamps were still paper so you could get ‚Äúreal money‚Äù back in change. We often ate at soup kitchens and I remember liking the food there better than the stuff we had at home. I was 8 years old and had no real idea what "poor" really meant. One of our fist apartments was across from cockroach park in Minneapolis. The official name was not cockroach park, but that was the name everyone in the neighborhood had for it. It is a little park tucked in by Cedar ave and Hiawatha about a block from Little Earth. Facing the park was, and is, a big church: Holy Rosary Catholic Church. The church is northwest  of Du Nord Craft Spirits. While talking to Lonnie the pieces coalesced in my head: The eight-year-old version of me had eaten dinners at Holy Rosary‚Ä¶ I was a guest of Loaves and Fishes. I remembered being able to take some food home too and being so happy to have it. Now in the midst of a pandemic nearly 30 years later, I was donating hand sanitizer to the organization that fed me as a child. We are in a time where our fates are so closely intertwined yet we are so isolated. Now more than ever we need to step up to help each other out. But for the donations of time and money that provided for those meals, I would have gone to bed hungry those nights in the winter of ‚Äô91. I have more emails than I can count from people wanting to help pay for or distribute sanitizer. I have staff who asked to be laid off if it would mean their coworkers could stay on the job. I have seen the Lonnys of the world in non-profits across the state double their efforts to help those in need.  I am humbled today, and I hope I stay that way. There is so much good out there and people are working so hard for their fellow brothers and sisters that I am sure we get to the other side of this better than we were before. I hope this message finds you all safe, warm, and well fed. -Chris Montana Husband/Dad/Owner, Du Nord Craft Spirits

Thank you to all of the people continuing to show up and care for our communities - people in health care, EMS, grocery stores, pharmacies, food shelves, teachers, and those in local and state government. Leave a message of thanks in the comments below.
Love the creativity and care Minnesota‚Äôs small business owners and community members are showing during this time.

Thank you to each and every one of the people on the frontline keeping our communities safe - doctors, nurses, those in public safety, and in hospitals and clinics. I am overwhelmed with gratitude for your service to Minnesota and I wanted to share just a few words of thanks.

Last night, the Senate passed a bipartisan coronavirus bill ‚Äî offering some much-needed relief to American families, small businesses, hospitals, and local and state governments. Some of the highlights of the bill include: -Unemployment benefits will be extended, expanded, and increased to help more workers -Forgivable loans will be available to support small businesses and nonprofits, so they can keep more people on their payroll and so more workers can keep their jobs -Hospitals will receive a significant increase in funding to support their services -Providers, especially those in rural areas, will receive increased Medicare payments to get much-needed funding -New investments will be made in COVID-19 research and in medical supplies -There will be worker and transparency protections on government loans -Direct monetary assistance for individuals and extra help for families with children During these negotiations, I fought tirelessly to ensure families, small businesses, and our health care workers were getting the resources they needed. I championed portions of the legislation that would ensure private insurance plans cover a COVID-19 vaccine without cost-sharing when it becomes available. I fought hard to put in place measures that would prevent drug shortages and protect our medical supply chain. I helped secure $3.5 billion in additional funding for child care assistance for frontline workers and made sure we are supporting our rural and telehealth programs. And I fought to secure more than $8 billion in critical funding for tribes and the Indian Health Service. But this is just the first step. As this public health and economic crisis deepens, I will continue to be a resource for all Minnesotans and fight for the needs of our communities. I will do everything in my power to work with state and local officials to ensure our families, hospitals, local governments, businesses, and community programs get the support they have been promised. I know the hard work is just getting started, and I am rolling up my sleeves to fiercely advocate on behalf of everyone. Trust me ‚Äî I am not done fighting for you. I hope you and your loved ones are staying healthy and safe.

I‚Äôm in Washington, working remotely from my apartment, doing everything I can to help complete a legislative package to help American families and small businesses respond to this unprecedented health and economic emergency.  I‚Äôm fighting to get more tests and health care supplies to Minnesota, and my staff and I have talked to hundreds of Minnesotans to get your best ideas for what we can do right now to help. The last few weeks have been incredibly difficult for so many Minnesotans, and Americans. Our hearts go out to those who have lost loved ones, and those that are suddenly worried sick about losing their financial security. And also, we are overwhelmed with gratitude for all the people who continue to work so that the rest of us have the health care, food, medicines, and basic supplies we all need.  I‚Äôm thinking of doctors and nurses and front line workers in health care and public safety, and the folks keeping child care centers running so these folks can go to work.  I‚Äôm thinking of the front line workers in grocery stores, pharmacies, factories and everywhere else we turn to get what we need.  I‚Äôm thinking of the farmers and ranchers, truck drivers and others working in food processing facilities and dairies ‚Äî working to make sure we have food to put on the table.  And I‚Äôm thinking of all the public servants in state, local and federal government, who have been working 24 hours a day to respond to this crisis. I want you all to know that I have never been more motivated to work for you in every way I know how to respond to this crisis in ways that put working families and small business first.  In times of great challenge like this, we show our strength. We truly are in this together. Paul Wellstone‚Äôs simple but profound statement, ‚ÄúWe all do better when we all do better‚Äù has never been more true. We have lots of work to do. Be careful out there.
We‚Äôve made progress on the federal response to COVID-19, but there‚Äôs still so much more we need to address.

I‚Äôm supporting Joe Biden because he‚Äôs shown me that he has the heart, the experience, and the values to lead us forward as President. I trust him to do what‚Äôs right for the state and country I love so much. I believe we are at a turning point in America, and that we must turn toward more justice, more freedom, and more opportunity for everyone, not just for those who are rich and well connected. We need Joe right now, because he understands what people‚Äôs lives are like, and he will put people, not himself, first. At the Democratic National Convention in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, our party will choose who best to unify us and lead our country forward. I will proudly support any Democratic nominee over President Trump, whose chaotic, self-serving Presidency is hurting Minnesotans every day. With Joe at the top of the ticket, I believe we bring people together to win the Presidency, and win elections up and down the ballot. With Joe, we can take back the Senate and say goodbye to Mitch McConnell‚Äôs cynical efforts to obstruct progress and put special interests before the people‚Äôs interests. We can fulfill the promise that every American has access to health care they can afford. We can lower prescription drug prices and protect and expand social security. We can take bold steps to address climate change and gun violence. We can get dark money out of our politics and defend voting rights and the rights of people to come together to organize for better wages and benefits and safe places to work. Democracy is not something that just happens, it takes hard work. Joe has been working to build a more perfect union his entire life, and I believe that he is the best person in this moment to lead us forward.
Team Tina here - it‚Äôs Tina‚Äôs birthday! LIKE this post to send her birthday greetings.
Time to get out and vote, Minnesota! Polls are open until 8PM - find your polling location here: https://pollfinder.sos.state.mn.us/

Amy Klobuchar campaigned with joy and lifted up the voices and concerns of working Americans. This campaign was true to Amy, John, Abigail and all the Americans who have been inspired by her pragmatic, progressive vision. Proud to call her a friend and to keep working together in the Senate.‚Ä¨

Precinct caucuses are TODAY! Find your location here: https://caucus.dfl.org/Senator Tina Smith wants you to attend your precinct caucus on February 25th! Go to https://www.dfl.org/caucus/ to find out how you can help better your community by meeting with your local organizing unit.
The House took action to lower the cost of prescription drugs for Minnesotans and people across the country. Now it's time for action in the Senate. ‚è∞

A St. Paul native, Mayor Melvin Carter‚Äôs roots in organizing energize and empower those around him to fight for change in their own community. In the Governor‚Äôs office, we worked together to get universal pre-K for all Minnesotans. Proud to continue working alongside him. #BHM
5 DAYS until Minnesota‚Äôs precinct caucuses. There are a lot of great reasons to caucus - tell us why you‚Äôre caucusing in the comments below.

ONE WEEK until Minnesota‚Äôs precinct caucuses! Precinct caucuses are your chance to make your voice heard and to participate in our democracy -- after all, it only works when WE participate. Find your caucus location here:Remember to attend your caucus on February 25th! Go to https://caucus.dfl.org/ to find your caucus location! Why are you caucusing? Share with us in the comments below!

Family farm bankruptcies are the highest they‚Äôve been in years. With agriculture at the heart of Minnesota‚Äôs economy, we‚Äôve got to keep fighting for our farmers and get more done alongside them - like the 2018 Farm Bill that I helped write and pass.
Happy Valentine's Day, Archie!

2019 was an historic year in the MN legislature, as a record number of Black and Somali-American legislators took office. They created MN‚Äôs first United Black Legislative Caucus, designed to lift up & address issues Black communities across MN face. #BHM
Spotted üëÄ Team Tina out door knocking! Join us and sign up to volunteer today: http://bit.ly/2K6F35s

Farji Shaheer knows the power of his voice & has used it as a force for change in MN. He created the Next Step program, working to prevent victims of violent injuries from returning with another injury from a violent crime. #BlackHistoryMonth

I just voted to remove Donald J. Trump from office. While I disagree with the President on a lot of issues, I believe impeachment should be the last resort. But when I read the whistleblower report alleging nothing less than the President‚Äôs corrupt abuse of power, we had no choice but to begin an impeachment inquiry. And when the House sent two articles of impeachment to the Senate, I took an oath to ‚Äúdo impartial justice according to the Constitution and the law.‚Äù That is an oath I take as seriously as anything I have ever done.  The trial wasn‚Äôt just about whether a president extorted allies for personal political favors and attempted to cover it up. It was about holding leaders accountable and defending our right to free, fair elections. And about the country we want to be and courage to fight for it. But a trial without witnesses and evidence is not a real trial. And an acquittal in such a trial is not a real acquittal either. Our duty to defend the Constitution requires action now. When the President solicits foreign nations to influence our elections with disinformation and prevents the public from hearing a full and fair account of that effort, we can‚Äôt afford to turn a blind eye.  There is nothing inevitable about democracy, it is something we have to fight for. And now, the fight for democracy and our Constitution has chosen us. We have a lot of work to do between now and November. Democracy is hard work. But I know you‚Äôre up to the task. This November, we can put our values on the record. Together, we can show our leaders will be held accountable. I see more signs of common ground, hope, and determination in MN than I do the fractures of division, distrust, and partisanship. This process may have let us down. But we must continue to hold onto the values that drive us to find common ground within our communities, to organize on the issues that matter most, and hold our elected leaders accountable. That matters. Thank you.

Last year, myself and other Minnesota legislators wrote to Secretary of Transportation, Elaine Chao, urging the department to grant funding for two new underpasses in Moorhead, MN. The result? The funding was denied.  Through this, I came to learn just how politicized the process of getting resources to communities that need them the most has become. It isn‚Äôt right. No matter the party, Americans want their leaders to prioritize their best interests -- not the interests of others in their party.
This is critical work. And we must get Savanna‚Äôs Act and the Not Invisible Act passed for women in Minnesota and all over the country.

This episode begins in St. Cloud, Minnesota. And already, right here in Minnesota, Trump‚Äôs campaign says they will have 100 staffers on the ground by summer. He only lost Minnesota by 1.5 points in 2016 and he‚Äôs set on winning the state in 2020. It‚Äôs going to take all of us to organize, organize, organize, so we can win on our values.New #TheWilderness: How can Democrats beat Trump‚Äôs divisive politics? Jon F. spends time with Obama-Trump voters in Milwaukee, and sits down with political leaders and strategists who know how to win in the Midwest.  "Chapter 5: The Midwest" out now: http://go.crooked.com/bEfY9H
Happy birthday, Archie! Here‚Äôs to another year of making us laugh.

It has been 47 years since the Supreme Court ruled in Roe v. Wade that abortion was legal. And today, abortion remains a critical service in our health care. But still, we see this right attacked and see attempts to undermine the provider-patient relationship. Believe me when I say that we will continue fighting together to protect abortion and to protect your choice to make decisions about your own body.If Republicans and the anti-choice movement want to cling to the past, they can have it. Progress moves forward‚Äîand we‚Äôre not going back.

It has been a decade since the Supreme Court ruled in Citizens United. And in that time - from 2010 to 2018 - more than $100 million has been spent in Minnesota by outside sources. It is time for us to put an end to outside influences in our elections and put an end to the hold dark money has on our democracy. It‚Äôs time for us to End Citizens United.

We are living through an historic time. When I was sworn into office as your Senator, I took an oath to uphold our Constitution and rule of law. Last fall, after learning about the President‚Äôs actions to get Ukraine to interfere in our elections for his personal political benefit, I came to the decision that the House should begin impeachment proceedings. We had no choice but to follow the facts, and establish whether the President abused his power and put his own interests ahead of the security of our nation and the rule of law. The House has impeached the President, and now the Senate begins a trial to determine if he should be removed from office. My duty to you and our democracy remains the same: To uphold the Constitution and rule of law, and the principle that no one is above the law. As a member of the Senate, I swear an oath to ‚Äúdo impartial justice, according to the Constitution and the law‚Äù and I take this oath seriously. The Senate must hold a fair trial, and that includes witnesses and evidence. Whatever happens, I will fulfill my duty, and make a judgment based on my job as a juror charged with providing impartial justice.

Happy Birthday, Dr. King. Today, we pause for a moment to be thankful for the legacy of Dr. King‚Äôs work for justice, and his dream that all people have the opportunity to live lives defined by freedom and dignity. Dr. King understood that the path of progress is not always a straight line. ‚ÄúProgress,‚Äù he wrote, ‚Äúdoes not roll in on wheels of inevitability.‚Äù Today, let‚Äôs not just remember Dr. King‚Äôs words, but act on them, and rededicate ourselves to the struggle - for voting rights, for human rights, for civil rights, and for true equality in our great but imperfect democracy.

MINNESOTA üó£ You can vote early for the presidential primary starting today! The presidential primary is on March 3, so make sure you vote on or before then. Find your early voting location or day-of polling place here: mnvotes.org
It‚Äôs time to step up and lead action on climate change.

Yesterday I visited with Mr. Harris's students at Richfield High School to hear about what is on their hearts and minds as young citizens of our state and country. They had great questions as we talked about the issues that matter most to them and how they can be engaged in the political process. Thanks for having me!
I believe everyone should get a fair shake at building the life they want. And here's how I'm going to make sure we are able to continue doing that together in 2020.
Wishing you a peaceful holiday and a happy new year!

This year, we did a lot together. Here are just a few things: ‚úÖ The cost of insulin continues to skyrocket -- and Minnesotans have died because they can't afford it. So I introduced legislation to make sure emergency access to insulin is available and will continue holding drugmakers accountable for the prices they set. ‚úÖ And great news on insulin: Another bipartisan bill that I introduced to bring down the cost of insulin and make more low-cost insulin options available was just signed into law. ‚úÖ When the government shutdown in January, federal contractors, like security guards and cafeteria workers, weren‚Äôt eligible to receive back pay. I stepped up, you raised your voices, to say that was wrong and introduced legislation to correct it. In June, the House passed it. We‚Äôre still waiting for it to be taken up in the Senate‚Ä¶ ‚úÖ This spring, I shared my experience from earlier in my life with depression. When I needed mental health care, help was available to me. I know this isn‚Äôt the case for everyone. It‚Äôs time we make mental health care available to all those who need it.  ‚úÖ You‚Äôve been speaking up for action on climate change. And this year, I wrote a bill that would take action on climate change now, reduce carbon emissions from the electric sector, and would make sure that all states would be able to take action in a way that works for their communities.  ‚úÖ I continue to hear from Minnesotans that they can‚Äôt afford their prescription drugs. So I got to work to introduce legislation that gives Medicare the power to negotiate prices and for Rx drugs to be imported. And I‚Äôll keep standing up to Big Pharma.   ‚úÖ Right now, where you live could determine childbirth outcomes. That‚Äôs not okay. It‚Äôs why I co-authored the Rural MOMS Act this year, so that communities have the resources they need to address these health disparities.  ‚úÖ For years, Liberians in MN have faced uncertainty of their future in the state. Many have put down roots here and are a vital part of our community and economy. We worked hard to find a permanent solution for their residency here -- and now, one has been signed into law. In November, it was one year since you elected me to office. It has been an honor serving you in the U.S. Senate and let me tell you -- I never imagined myself in this position, but every single day I am grateful to raise your voice and fight. Let‚Äôs keep fighting together.
A little Minnesota and Wisconsin trivia before tomorrow‚Äôs game‚Ä¶

Many Liberians moved to Minnesota seeking refuge from civil wars and got Deferred Enforced Departure status. Many have been here for decades, have put down roots here, and are a vital part of our community and economy. The DED status has offered only temporary protections -- until now. I‚Äôm proud of the work we did together to find a permanent solution and one that offers a pathway to citizenship.
Maternal health shouldn‚Äôt be dependent on where you live. But right now, it is. I‚Äôve co-authored a bill to help rural communities create new ways to ensure mothers have the care they need.
We need to listen to our young citizens who are stepping up and calling for action.

‚ÄúThere are people dying from this insulin crisis. I feel like the worst has happened, and if that‚Äôs not enough for them, I‚Äôm just not sure what it will take for them to come to a conclusion in a timely manner.‚Äù - Meghan Mateuszczyk Meghan‚Äôs right ‚Äî we need to take action now to lower the cost of insulin.
Abortion is health care. And we will keep fighting to make sure it stays legal.
Today we remember all those who lost their lives at Pearl Harbor 78 years ago, including Dante Tini who finally arrived home to Minnesota earlier this year.

All across Minnesota, all across our country, so many of us have a fight that feels personal. Whether it‚Äôs making sure kids have access to mental health care, making sure our rural communities are creating opportunities for the next generation, making sure immigrants we‚Äôre proud to call our neighbors feel welcome and safe. When we come together to fight for one another, each of our fights - no matter what they are - solidifies our belief that opportunity is supposed to be for everyone. I‚Äôm proud to be in this fight to win this Senate seat with each and every one of you.

Last week I had the opportunity to visit Two Harbors to listen to what we can be doing to better support the community. I‚Äôm grateful for the business and community leaders who took the time to meet with me and I‚Äôm excited for our work ahead.
The benefits of thousands of Minnesotans are at risk and I‚Äôm committed to finding a solution that doesn‚Äôt result in Minnesotans paying for a problem they didn‚Äôt create.
We can‚Äôt wait any longer to take action on this crisis.

Today I‚Äôm giving thanks for Minnesotans across the state who take time to share their stories with me, for the opportunity to fight on behalf of you in the Senate every day, and for my family who supports me along the way. Happy Thanksgiving, everyone!

‚ÄúI am not interested in recreating foods from 1491 -- rather, I hope to celebrate the diversity that defines our communities now.‚Äù - Sean Sherman, The Sioux Chef Sean‚Äôs words in The New York Times demonstrate so clearly his passion for sharing authentic Indigenous foods from across North America. Take time to read Sean‚Äôs story, learn about the foods he uses, and the why behind them.
Insulin costs too much in this country. And we‚Äôve got to figure out how to bring down the cost for families.

Mitch McConnell refuses to bring the Violence Against Women Act up for a vote. It‚Äôs startling and disappointing that we can‚Äôt move on this bill -- a bill that protects women from violence and has the potential to empower tribal courts to prosecute acts of violence committed by non-Native people on tribal land.

NPR reports that the Public Service Loan Forgiveness Program is rejecting 99% of people who believe they‚Äôve met the program requirements, yet in reality they‚Äôve been given inaccurate information by loan servicing companies. My colleagues and I are demanding that the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau investigate this matter. This program is supposed to be helping address student loan debt ‚Äî not creating more problems.
2019 began with a 35-day government shutdown. And now, as we approach the end of 2019, federal contract workers STILL haven‚Äôt received back pay from the shutdown.

On this Veterans Day, I‚Äôm reflecting on those who have risked their lives to protect us all, our brave military servicemembers who remain in harm‚Äôs way, and our moral obligation each and every day to support those who have served. Thank you to our veterans for their bravery, sacrifice, and service and to the family members who support them. I‚Äôm particularly grateful for organizations and programs in Minnesota like this who step up and support veterans in a multitude of ways, allowing them to thrive here at home.
Grateful to be surrounded today by so many women driven by their values and motivated to fight for a better future.
One year ago, Minnesotans elected me to the Senate. And every day since, I've been grateful to serve you in Washington. Let's keep working for progress together.

Minnesota üó£ Today is Election Day! There are local elections happening across the state and now is your opportunity to make your voice heard. Find out what‚Äôs on your ballot and find your polling place at mnvotes.org.

Your seasonal reminder that the November 2020 election is 368 days away. PS - Minnesota, your local elections are only 5 days away! Make sure you know what‚Äôs on your ballot and then vote on Tuesday.

No surprises here - still no plans for what they‚Äôre going to do after taking away health care coverage from millions of Americans and still no plan to make sure there are protections for people with pre-existing conditions.
This is a win in the fight for reproductive health care and reproductive rights. Keep fighting. I‚Äôm in this with you.

I believe we have a duty to look at all of the facts and use the facts to guide our actions. And I believe that we will look back at this moment and remember whether we spoke out or remained silent.  I‚Äôve spent time reviewing the facts, reflecting on my duty as your Senator to uphold the law, and I‚Äôve come to a decision: the House should begin impeachment proceedings. I support the beginning of these proceedings, because it‚Äôs a matter of national security and protecting our Constitution and the rule of law. We must open a process to lay out the facts, as we continue to learn of reports that the President asked - or pressured - Ukraine to interfere in our country‚Äôs democracy, specifically by undermining a political opponent. This impeachment inquiry is serious -- and different from removal from office. In our system of checks and balances, an impeachment inquiry is the only way we are able to establish whether a President has abused their power and put their own interests ahead of the security of our nation and the rule of law.  As your Senator, my job is to uphold the Constitution and rule of law. And that means fulfilling my responsibility to listen to all of the evidence before making a final judgment. I‚Äôm speaking out, because I believe it is my duty to you and our democracy.

There are no off-years in elections. It‚Äôs all about engaging people, having conversations with our friends, neighbors, people we live with -- everyone needs to be engaged in this election. Tuition is rising faster than the cost of living, causing many Minnesotans to take out student loans to pay for higher education. In fact, in 2017, Minnesotans took out a combined total of $1.1 billion in student loans. As I travel across Minnesota, common themes arise and one of the main recent themes is the cost and availability of housing. I‚Äôve heard again and again about the mismatch between housing people can afford and what is being built, resulting in instability for so many Minnesotans. Here‚Äôs what I know: If you don‚Äôt have a safe place to call home, nothing else in your life works. So I‚Äôm taking what I heard back to the Senate to work on solutions.

In honor of Mother‚Äôs Day, I share this classic Smith Family photo. To all you mothers (and fathers) out there, I wonder if any of this looks familiar? 1.  I had clearly prepared for this ‚Äúcasual‚Äù photo, since I was wearing lipstick, a skirt, and even a necklace. I can promise you this was not how I normally looked when Sam and Mason were toddlers. 2.  Sam thought the bicycle helmet he was wearing was a football helmet. This explains the tiny football. He gave up football shortly after this picture was taken.  Adorable. 3.  Mason looks concerned, probably because I was trying to break him of his attachment to the bottle he was so blissfully enjoying. The good news is that it was just water in the bottle. The bad news is that he was very, very attached. Adorable. 4.  And Archie. He is really adorable. He (and I) look so young! So much of the lives ahead of us we could never have imagined. Like that I would end up as United States Senator. And that Archie would end up with a prince named after him. I love these guys, and also Emily and Julia, who have hitched their wagons (this is something my mother would have said) to Sam and Mason and our family. Being their Mother is joyful and endlessly fascinating and full of love. And I still worry about them. Happy Mothers Day to all you wonderful mothers out there, who dressed up for photos, did your best, love your children with joy and fascination, and still worry about them, even when they are all grown up.

There is still so much progress to be made. There are two women in particular that have inspired me in this fight. My grandmother Avis Iden Mason is one of the women I think about. She was born in 1898, went to college (which was a big deal for women in those days), and then came home to Indiana to be the President of the community bank that her father founded. She did this while raising 7 children including my mother, and lived into her late 80s. Dr. Josie Johnson is a friend, mentor and the most gracious, savvy, wise woman I know. She led a delegation from Minnesota to Mississippi in 1964 to witness the civil rights struggle and helped found the Minneapolis Department of Civil Rights. Later, Josie became the first African-American appointed to the Board of Regents at the University of Minnesota. I wish I could name every accomplishment and every life she has touched, but it‚Äôs a tribute to her that the list is too long to name.  What woman has inspired you?
